questions.question: Ableism is the discrimination prejudice against people who identify as a different gender than what they are born as.
Ableism can take form in all of these ways except:

choices.answer: Not being able to legally marry one's partner
Segregating students with disabilities in a different school
Assuming that disabled people need to be "fixed"
Failing to incorporate accessibility in buildings

questions.question: This is an example of "everyday" ableism: assuming someone has to have a visible disability to be disabled
This is an example of "everyday" ableism: casting a disabled actor to play a disabled role
All of these are examples of "everyday" ableism except for:

choices.answer: Using someone's mobility device as a hand or foot rest
Asking someone how they became disabled
Talking to someone with a disability as if they were a child
Making a movie with closed captioning

questions.question: Micro-agressions are blatant and overt insults relating to someone's gender, race, sex, disability, etc.
This is an example of a micro-aggression: "Your hair looks okay today."
This is an example of a micro-aggression: "You are so retarded."
All of these is an example of a micro-aggression except for:

choices.answer: I'm super OCD about my apartment.
Are you off of your meds?

questions.question: Micro-aggressions are harmful because they assume that people with disabilities are inferior or need to be fixed.
All of these are great ways to recognize and avert ableism except for:

choices.answer: Believe someone when they disclose that they have a disability.
Listen to people when they request accomodation.
Don't touch a person with a disability or their equipment without consent.
Use bathrooms designed for people with disabilities.

questions.question: We should all become more informed about ways to help people with disabilities.
